newsitem.title: NORWAY: BNbank shares jump on DnB offer.
newsitem.headline: BNbank shares jump on DnB offer.

text.p: Shares in Norway's leading mortgage lender largest Bolig og Naeringsbanken (BNbank) jumped more than four percent on Friday after the country's top bank, Den norske Bank ASA (DnB), launched a take-over bid and started a bidding battle for the niche group.
At 1135 GMT, BNbank was 8.50 crowns up at 202 crowns in heavy turnover of 103 million crowns.
DnB's bid came three days after the fourth largest commercial bank Fokus Bank ASA proposed a merger with BNbank.

DnB said it would offer a cash payment of 184.50 crowns per share, plus BNbank's 1996 dividend of 10.50 crowns. This compares with Fokus' proposed exchange ratio of 3.3 shares in Fokus for each share in BNbank, with 20 percent of the consideration paid in cash.
Analysts said DnB was likely to be the successful bidder, although they expected Fokus to raise its exchange ratio and for DnB to subsequently raise its cash offer before the battle was settled.

"DnB has got much more muscle than Fokus and the board at BNbank would probably prefer DnB," said one analyst. "But I expect a bidding war and in the end it will be BNbank shareholders who come out on top."
